description: proportion of correct answers for end of chapter questions for current chapter
students can "access" the video multiple times (e.g., press play); this number tells you how many times video has been accessed so far (e.g., 1 is the first time video was accessed; 2 is second time)
the number of times the question has been attempted, including the current attempt
the book name
the chapter that the item appears in
the chapter (as a number)
the chapter (as a number). Probably redundant information
a unique identifier for this particular class

whether this response completed the page. After completing that item, the student has no more items to complete on that page. Thus, if TRUE occurs for an earlier item, we can infer that the student skipped that item and then went back and did it last.

The psychological construct measured by the pulse-check item. One of cost, expectancy, Intrinstic Value, Utility Value. These items are meant to gauge the student's attitudes about the content being studied.
the text that appears in the hint box
the code run invisibly to set up the module
the code run invisibly to set up the module
the solution checking code (see the testwhat package for details)
the code that appears in the solution tab
A datetime object indicating when the page was accessed (timezone: GMT/UTC)
a datetime object indicating when the video was last interacted with (timezone: GMT/UTC)
a datetime object indicating when the video was first started (timezone: GMT/UTC)
a datetime object indicating when the response was submitted (timezone: GMT/UTC)

The amount of time the user was considered "engaged", in milliseconds, in the material. To maintain engagement, the user must do something on the page (click, mouse movement, scroll, etc.) at least every 2 minutes.

The sum of time the user was considered"idle" for a"brief" period of time. A user is considered"idle" if they are on the page but are not"engaged". The time period is considered"brief" if it is less than 15 minutes. Note that the"idle" periods are retroactively tagged such that the period will start at the last known engagement activity. For a concrete example: 1. user clicks something; 2. reads one minute; 3. clicks something; 4. leaves, comes back 10 minutes later; 5. clicks something. This user would be considered engaged for 1 minute, then idle for 10 minutes. The caveat to this approach is that if they user read the screen for 5 minutes, then left and came back, they would still be considered idle for all of them. This is likely a rare scenario, and in any event, one we can't detect anyway.

The sum of times that the user was considered"idle" for a"long" period of time. A user is considered"idle" if they are on the page but are not"engaged". The time period is considered"long" if it is more than 15 minutes.
a unique identifier for the institution the class was taken at
a unique identifier for this particular question
whether this is a learnosity (question about non-coding content)  item or a coding item
notes: "learnosity" is a software platform for generating questions and assessments.  A "learnosity item" is one created in this platform and will be a question or activity assessing the content of the book. A coding item will one in which the student enters or corrects R code.

description: the unique ID for the activity on Learnosity
a datetime object indicating when the responses was saved (timezone: GMT/UTC)
a datetime object indicating when the responses was started (timezone: GMT/UTC)
the status of the item on Learnosity (e.g."published")

for Learnosity items that have multiple answer options (like multiple-choice, Likert ratings, etc.) these are the 0-indexed options the student could choose from (i.e., the first answer choice is represented with 0; second answer choice is represented as 1)
for multi-question items, the position of the question in the item
the unique ID for the question on Learnosity
the unique ID for this particular response on Learnosity
the status of the question response on Learnosity (e.g."Completed")
the template used to create the item
the Learnosity type of the question (e.g. mcq, shorttext, plaintext, rating, etc.)
the unique identifier for the video
The number of attempts to answer the end of chapter questions as a whole. For example, if there were three questions, and the 2nd question was attempted twice, the n_attemps is 4.
The number of end-of-chapter questions that were correct for the current chapter
The number of end-of-chapter questions for the current chapter and so the highest possible score.

The sum of timet the user was considered"off page" for a"brief" period of time. A user is considered"off page" if they have the page open but the page is not focused (e.g.it is open in another tab or the browser is not the active program). The time period is considered"brief" if it is less than 15 minutes.

The sum of the periods that the user was considered"off page" for a"long" period of time. A user is considered"off page" if they have the page open but the page is not focused (e.g. it is open in another tab or the browser is not the active program). The time period is considered"long" if it is more than 15 minutes.
the page that the item appears on; includes the title, chapter and section.
the page that the item appears on (as a number; 4.1, the first page in chapter 4, is represented as 4.01 in order to distinguish it from 4.10, the 10th page in chapter 4)
the number of points earned
the number of points possible if the completely correct answer is given
the question prompt for this response

the proportion of the full video runtime that the student has spent watching a video, regardless of which part of the video they watched (e.g. if the video is 10 seconds long, and the student watches the first 5 seconds three times, this value should be 1.5)
the proportion of the video that student has watched, summed across all interactions with the video
release version (version of the book, e.g., 5.0.1, 5.1, 5.3); named for the github branch for the materials

the value of the response: either the value (for shorttext, plaintext, ratings, datacamp, etc.) or an array of numbers indicating the position of the multiple choice answers chosen and which correspond to the columns lrn_option_.
indicates whether the item was part of a chapter review
The section number of a page. For example, for page 1.04 the section number is 4.
unique id identifying a student
Number of "try again" clicks (once students complete a page, they can reset the page to "try again") regardless of whether that "try again" button was pushed on this access time
A datetime object indicating the latest time when the "try again" button was clicked (timezone: GMT/UTC)
the browser user agent string for the user (see for details: https://developer.chrome.com/multidevice/user-agent; also, this R package for parsing: uaparserjs)
When the student accessed the page, were they coming back after already having completed it?
